results.title: Israel Bombards Hezbollah as Group’s Leader Vows Retaliation
results.abstract: The Hezbollah leader, Hassan Nasrallah, did not say how his group would respond to attacks on hand-held devices, which killed dozens when pagers and walkie-talkies exploded.
results.byline: By Aaron Boxerman and Euan Ward

multimedia.caption: Hezbollah supporters in Beirut on Thursday mourned the deaths of two of their members in a second wave of explosions that struck Lebanon.
multimedia.copyright: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

results.title: A New Era in Sabotage: Turning Ordinary Devices Into Grenades, on a Mass Scale
results.abstract: The attacks in Lebanon required getting deep into the supply chain, which is difficult to do. But the sabotage contributes to a sense of vulnerability that ordinary devices can become a source of danger.

multimedia.caption: A portable radio with the battery removed during a funeral in Beirut, Lebanon, on Wednesday. The presumed Israeli sabotage of wireless devices used by Hezbollah turned ordinary communication devices into miniature grenades.
multimedia.copyright: Anwar Amro/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

multimedia.caption: A portable radio with the battery removed during a funeral in Beirut, Lebanon, on Wednesday. The presumed Israeli sabotage of wireless devices used by Hezbollah turned ordinary communication devices into miniature grenades.

results.title: North Carolina Governor Race Jolted by Report That G.O.P. Nominee Called Himself a ‘Black Nazi’
results.abstract: Mr. Robinson, the Republican nominee for governor of North Carolina, vowed to stay in the race and sought to deny the report, which also said he had defended slavery in online posts years ago.
results.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Nicholas Nehamas

multimedia.caption: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina spoke at the Republican National Convention in July.

results.title: How the Robinson Report Could Affect the Presidential Race in North Carolina
results.abstract: A Democratic presidential candidate has not won North Carolina since 2008. But the drama around Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, the Republican nominee for governor, is sure to bolster their hopes.

multimedia.caption: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, who is running for governor of North Carolina, has a history of making inflammatory remarks.

results.title: How North Carolina Republicans Could Replace Their Governor Nominee
results.abstract: The deadline for a candidate to withdraw is midnight tonight, but Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson has vowed to stay in the race.

results.abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris spoke off the cuff, as guests included a teenager shot at her school and the family of a woman in Georgia who died as a result of the state’s abortion ban.

results.title: Trump Says That if He Loses, ‘the Jewish People Would Have a Lot to Do’ With It
results.abstract: Speaking at a campaign event denouncing antisemitism in America, Donald Trump again attacked Jews who vote for Democrats, saying that the party had a “hold, or curse, on you.”
results.byline: By Chris Cameron and Michael Gold

multimedia.caption: “With all I have done for Israel, I received only 24 percent of the Jewish vote,” former President Donald J. Trump said on Thursday at an event about fighting antisemitism. He added that “I really haven’t been treated very well, but it’s the story of my life.”
multimedia.copyright: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “With all I have done for Israel, I received only 24 percent of the Jewish vote,” former President Donald J. Trump said on Thursday at an event about fighting antisemitism. He added that “I really haven’t been treated very well, but it’s the story of my life.”

results.title: Prehistoric Earth Was Very Hot. That Offers Clues About Future Earth.
results.abstract: At times during the past half-billion years, carbon dioxide warmed our planet more than previously thought, according to a new reconstruction of Earth’s deep past.

results.title: Europe’s New Defense Chief: ‘A King Without a Kingdom’?
results.abstract: The European Union has vowed to enhance its military capability. But money is scarce, responsibilities overlap and the new job is less about soldiers than arms manufacturers.

results.title: Inside the Secretive Facility Housing Migrants at Guantánamo Bay
results.abstract: Reports and interviews shed new light on the holding center, where migrants’ calls with lawyers are monitored and some say they’ve been forced to wear blackout goggles.

results.title: The Author of ‘Impossible Creatures’ Tucks Big Ideas in Tales of Wonder
results.abstract: Katherine Rundell said children can handle hefty themes, but finds it “bad manners to offer a child a story and give them just a moral.”

multimedia.caption: Katherine Rundell’s work is infused with both wonder and worry. “The unifying thread is that our world, as chaotic and burning as it is, demands our astonishment because of its beauty, its generosity and its intricate variety,” she said.
multimedia.copyright: Ellie Smith for The New York Times
